primitive_props.translation: Michael Scott Shemansky is on the run.
primitive_props.evidence: “Michael Scott Shemansky is on the run…”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic status claim about Shemansky being on the run; no logical connective.

primitive_props.translation: Authorities named Michael Scott Shemansky as a suspect in the murder of his mother.
primitive_props.evidence: “…after authorities named him as a suspect in the murder of his mother.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic claim about an action by authorities (naming him a suspect) tied to a specific case.

primitive_props.translation: Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted as a suspect in the murder of his own mother.
primitive_props.evidence: “A Florida man wanted as a suspect in the murder of his own mother…”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic “wanted as suspect” status; does not assert guilt.

primitive_props.translation: Michael Scott Shemansky has been on the run from police since Saturday.
primitive_props.evidence: “…has been on the run from police since Saturday.”

primitive_props.translation: Michael Scott Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son.
primitive_props.evidence: “…after he failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son…”

primitive_props.translation: Sandra Shemansky was found dead.
primitive_props.evidence: “…mother Sandra Shemansky , 57 , was found dead…”

primitive_props.translation: Sandra Shemansky was found dead at the home she shared with Michael Scott Shemansky in Winter Garden.
primitive_props.evidence: “…was found dead at the home they shared in Winter Garden.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic location/context claim about where she was found.

primitive_props.translation: Sandra Shemansky’s body was discovered at the West Colonial Drive home.
primitive_props.evidence: “The body was discovered at the West Colonial Drive home…”

primitive_props.translation: An out-of-state family member called in a well-being check.
primitive_props.evidence: “…when an out-of-state family member called in a well-being check.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic action claim about the call.

primitive_props.translation: An initial investigation determined there was foul play.
primitive_props.evidence: “WKMG reports that an initial investigation determined there was foul play.”

primitive_props.translation: Natalie Randall is a neighbor.
primitive_props.evidence: “…said neighbor Natalie Randall…”

primitive_props.translation: Natalie Randall is a resident of the Winter Garden RV Resort.
primitive_props.evidence: “…a resident of the Winter Garden RV Resort.”

primitive_props.translation: An attorney for Shemansky’s estranged wife confirmed Shemansky’s failure to appear for the scheduled visit.
primitive_props.evidence: “An attorney for his estranged wife confirmed Shemansky 's failure to appear for the scheduled visit.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic confirmation claim by an attorney.

primitive_props.translation: Michael Scott Shemansky is on parole for battery on law enforcement.
primitive_props.evidence: “He is already on parole for battery on law enforcement…”

primitive_props.translation: Michael Scott Shemansky has a history of bipolar mental illness.
primitive_props.evidence: “…has a history of bipolar mental illness…”

primitive_props.translation: Michael Scott Shemansky was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward.
primitive_props.evidence: “…was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward…”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic commitment fact; separated from purpose/reason.

primitive_props.translation: Michael Scott Shemansky attempted suicide.
primitive_props.evidence: “…to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide.”

primitive_props.translation: Sandra Shemansky was helping Michael Scott Shemansky as he went through a divorce.
primitive_props.evidence: “His mother was there to help him as he went through a divorce.”

primitive_props.translation: Shemansky’s wife filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago.
primitive_props.evidence: “His wife filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago…”

primitive_props.translation: Authorities have the murder weapon.
primitive_props.evidence: “Authorities have the murder weapon…”

primitive_props.translation: The murder weapon has not been publicly identified.
primitive_props.evidence: “…still not publicly identified…”

primitive_props.translation: Authorities will not yet confirm how Sandra Shemansky was killed.
primitive_props.evidence: “…will not yet confirm how Sandra Shemansky was killed…”

primitive_props.translation: Michael Scott Shemansky was seen going into the trailer park’s office.
primitive_props.evidence: “He allegedly was seen going into the trailer park 's office…”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic observation claim (seen going into office), separated from purpose; marked later as soft via constraints.

primitive_props.translation: Michael Scott Shemansky asked for a glass of water in the trailer park’s office.
primitive_props.evidence: “…and asking for a glass of water…”

primitive_props.translation: Michael Scott Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot.
primitive_props.evidence: “Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot…”

primitive_props.translation: When last seen, Michael Scott Shemansky had no provisions.
primitive_props.evidence: “…without any sort of provisions…”

primitive_props.translation: When last seen, Michael Scott Shemansky had no medication.
primitive_props.evidence: “…and no medication.”

primitive_props.translation: Authorities urge anyone with information about Shemansky’s whereabouts to contact authorities at 407-656-3636.
primitive_props.evidence: “Anyone with information as to his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities at 407-656-3636.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic report of an urging/request (a factual statement in the article).

primitive_props.translation: Sandra Shemansky is Michael Scott Shemansky’s mother.
primitive_props.evidence: “…the murder of his mother… mother Sandra Shemansky…”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic kinship relation stated by apposition (“mother Sandra”).

primitive_props.translation: Sandra Shemansky was murdered.
primitive_props.evidence: “…suspect in the murder of his mother.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic classification of the death as a murder (as framed by the text).

primitive_props.translation: Michael Scott Shemansky murdered Sandra Shemansky.
primitive_props.evidence: Implied by “suspect in the murder of his mother” (as the alleged perpetrator).
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic perpetration claim; included separately because being a suspect is not the same as having committed the murder.

primitive_props.translation: Natalie Randall is concerned that Shemansky might come back.
primitive_props.evidence: “‘My biggest concern is that he might come back,’ said neighbor Natalie Randall…”

primitive_props.translation: Neighbors said Sandra Shemansky was preventing Shemansky from making the meeting with his son.
primitive_props.evidence: “Neighbors said his mother may have been the one preventing him from making the meeting with his son.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic reported-claim by neighbors (kept as a single statement about what neighbors said).

primitive_props.translation: Neighbors at the Winter Garden RV Resort believe the divorce proceedings pushed Shemansky over the edge.
primitive_props.evidence: “Neighbors at the Winter Garden RV Resort believe divorce proceedings may have pushed Shemansky over the edge.”

primitive_props.translation: Nathan Tanner said Sandra Shemansky would not allow Shemansky to go to the meeting with his son.
primitive_props.evidence: “‘His mom wouldn’t allow him to go,’ Nathan Tanner told reporters.”

primitive_props.translation: Nathan Tanner said Shemansky received paperwork Friday.
primitive_props.evidence: “‘And he got some paperwork Friday…’ Tanner told WFTV.”

primitive_props.translation: Nathan Tanner said the paperwork triggered Shemansky.
primitive_props.evidence: “…‘and I guess that triggered him,’ Tanner told WFTV.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic reported-claim about causation/triggering (as stated by Tanner).

primitive_props.translation: Shemansky’s estranged wife is preparing to protect herself if Shemansky arrives at her home.
primitive_props.evidence: “His estranged wife is reportedly preparing to protect himself on the chance he arrives at her home.”
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic preparedness claim (noting the text says “reportedly” and contains a pronoun inconsistency).

hard_constraints.translation: If Shemansky has been on the run from police since Saturday, then he is on the run.
hard_constraints.evidence: “has been on the run from police since Saturday” and “is on the run”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Being on the run from police since a time entails being on the run (semantic entailment).

hard_constraints.translation: If he is wanted as a suspect in the murder of his mother, then authorities have named him a suspect in that murder.
hard_constraints.evidence: “wanted as a suspect…” and “authorities named him as a suspect…”
hard_constraints.reasoning: In common usage, being ‘wanted as a suspect’ presupposes official designation as a suspect.

hard_constraints.translation: If authorities named him a suspect in the murder of his mother, then Sandra Shemansky is his mother.
hard_constraints.reasoning: The text identifies the mother as Sandra Shemansky (apposition); the ‘his mother’ in the murder reference is Sandra.

hard_constraints.translation: If Sandra Shemansky was murdered, then she was dead (found dead).
hard_constraints.evidence: “murder of his mother” and “was found dead”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Murder entails death; the article also explicitly says she was found dead.

hard_constraints.translation: If she was found dead at the shared home, then she was found dead.
hard_constraints.evidence: “…was found dead at the home they shared…”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Location-specific ‘found dead’ entails the general ‘found dead’.

hard_constraints.translation: If her body was discovered at the West Colonial Drive home, then she was found dead.
hard_constraints.reasoning: Discovering the body in this context entails she was dead/found dead.

hard_constraints.translation: If the attorney confirmed Shemansky’s failure to appear for the scheduled visit, then Shemansky failed to appear for the supervised visit with his son.
hard_constraints.evidence: Attorney confirmation sentence + earlier failure-to-appear sentence
hard_constraints.reasoning: Confirmation of the same failure entails the underlying failure occurred as described.

hard_constraints.translation: If Shemansky was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward (for an attempted suicide), then he attempted suicide.
hard_constraints.evidence: “…involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: The text gives the purpose/reason (“for an attempted suicide”); commitment for that reason entails the attempt occurred.

hard_constraints.translation: If authorities have the murder weapon, then Sandra Shemansky was murdered.
hard_constraints.evidence: “Authorities have the murder weapon…” in a story framed as a murder investigation
hard_constraints.reasoning: Calling it a ‘murder weapon’ presupposes a murder occurred (semantic presupposition in the article’s framing).

hard_constraints.translation: If the murder weapon has not been publicly identified, then (there is) a murder weapon that authorities have.
hard_constraints.evidence: “…still not publicly identified” immediately following “Authorities have the murder weapon”
hard_constraints.reasoning: An ‘unidentified murder weapon’ in context is the same weapon authorities possess; identification-status presupposes existence/possession as stated.

hard_constraints.translation: If Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot, then he is on the run.
hard_constraints.evidence: “last seen fleeing on foot” + “is on the run”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Fleeing to avoid capture is a core meaning of being ‘on the run’ (semantic entailment).

hard_constraints.translation: If Shemansky murdered Sandra Shemansky, then Sandra Shemansky was murdered.
hard_constraints.evidence: General semantic relationship between perpetration and event
hard_constraints.reasoning: Perpetration implies the event occurred (semantic entailment).

hard_constraints.translation: If authorities named him a suspect in the murder of his mother, then the text is treating Sandra Shemansky’s death as a murder.
hard_constraints.evidence: “…suspect in the murder of his mother”
hard_constraints.reasoning: In the narrative frame, ‘suspect in the murder’ asserts the case is a murder case (even if details are unconfirmed).

soft_constraints.translation: If there was foul play, then Sandra Shemansky was murdered.
soft_constraints.evidence: “initial investigation determined there was foul play”
soft_constraints.reasoning: Foul play often implies homicide/murder, but foul play could in principle include non-murder scenarios; thus defeasible.

soft_constraints.translation: Shemansky was seen going into the trailer park’s office.
soft_constraints.evidence: “He allegedly was seen going into the trailer park 's office…”
soft_constraints.reasoning: Marked by hedge word “allegedly,” so treated as uncertain.

soft_constraints.translation: Shemansky asked for a glass of water in the trailer park’s office.
soft_constraints.evidence: “He allegedly was seen… asking for a glass of water…”

soft_constraints.translation: Neighbors said Sandra Shemansky was preventing Shemansky from making the meeting with his son.
soft_constraints.evidence: “Neighbors said his mother may have been the one preventing him…”
soft_constraints.reasoning: Contains hedge “may have been” and is attributed to neighbors; not asserted as fact.

soft_constraints.translation: Neighbors believe the divorce proceedings pushed Shemansky over the edge.
soft_constraints.evidence: “…believe divorce proceedings may have pushed Shemansky over the edge.”
soft_constraints.reasoning: Belief attribution + hedge “may”; not established fact.

soft_constraints.translation: Nathan Tanner said Sandra Shemansky would not allow Shemansky to go to the meeting with his son.
soft_constraints.evidence: “‘His mom wouldn’t allow him to go,’ Nathan Tanner told reporters.”
soft_constraints.reasoning: This is a quote/claim by a neighbor, not independently confirmed.

soft_constraints.translation: Nathan Tanner said Shemansky received paperwork Friday.
soft_constraints.reasoning: Reported speech with “I guess” context; uncertain.

soft_constraints.translation: Nathan Tanner said the paperwork triggered Shemansky.
soft_constraints.reasoning: Explicit hedge “I guess”; causal attribution is speculative.

soft_constraints.translation: Shemansky’s estranged wife is preparing to protect herself if he arrives at her home.
soft_constraints.reasoning: Hedge word “reportedly” and pronoun inconsistency (“protect himself”) make it uncertain.

soft_constraints.translation: Natalie Randall is concerned that Shemansky might come back.
soft_constraints.evidence: “My biggest concern is that he might come back”
soft_constraints.reasoning: This is her stated concern (certain she is concerned), but the embedded possibility (“might come back”) indicates the feared event is uncertain; kept soft as it often functions as a speculative risk statement.

soft_constraints.translation: If he is a suspect, then he did not murder Sandra Shemansky.
soft_constraints.reasoning: Not entailed by the text; included as a defeasible principle that suspect status should not be equated with guilt.
